name: Alexander House Booklovers Bed and Breakfast

reviews.title: Great place
reviews.text: The place is awesome -- romantic and relaxing. My husband and I stayed there for our anniversary. Food was delicious and Elizabeth gave us a brown bag to eat on the road, as we would drive to the beach and explore the rest of the region. We definitely felt welcomed!

reviews.title: Like books, charming homes, and historic towns?
reviews.text: Five stars go to Elizabeth and Peter, hosts of Princess Anne's Booklovers B&B, and the townsfolk of Pr. Anne are very fortunate to have them! My husband and I spent a wonderful Valentine's Day weekend, complete with poetry readings of love poems, sonnets, etc. in their Cafe Collette on Sat. night. Peter and Elizabeth are quite a team and she has great culinary gifts (her breakfast crepes cannot be beat) and his woodworking/renovative skills have done wonders for the Alexander home. They also have a cozy sitting/reading room where time almost stands still for quiet reading/work/reflection. If you are looking for a restorative B&B in a quiet, historic town w/little traffic, try the Alexander house and don't forget your books! Gwen Frazier

reviews.title: Wonderful retreat
reviews.text: Loved the Jane Austen room and reading out on the porch. Elizabeth is a knowledgable and welcoming host. We will definately return.

reviews.title: Compliments
reviews.text: Winding your way to Ocean City, MD and/or the locale? Have an enjoyable stay in Princess Anne at the Alexander House, Booklovers B and B. The inn keepers are so personable; the breakfasts are delicious... the Jane Austen room is beautiful. Treat yourself to a lovely, relaxing evening or two.

reviews.title: Wonderful American place with a French atmosphere
reviews.text: Wonderful place, full of charm. The crepes, fantastique!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The weather forecast couldn't have been more dismal--pouring rain for days on end. Elizabeth generously offered to reschedule us for no extra charge, but we were in town for a wedding. After wonderful crepes in the cheery "cafe," we curled up in the comfy reading parlor for hours--wish it had been nice enough to enjoy the porch. We were in the spacious Jane Austen room, with its large bath, for two nights. Wonderful art deco furniture in the medium-size Langston Hughes room. The Robert Louis Stevenson room is small, but has a decent size bathroom.
reviews.title: Cozy respite on a rainy weekend

reviews.text: Elizabeth is a gracious hostess--ready to chat if you're interested but staying in the background if you're not. The decor is engaging throughout, and the entire inn is spotless. Bring your slippers--no shoes beyond the entry hall.
reviews.title: Respite for the Weary

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I stayed at the Alexander Bed and Breakfast in Princess Anne while on business in Salisbury. Three words describe the visit best: It Was Fabulous! Each night I returned "home" to the Alexander House from long and sometimes tense days to a much-needed, quiet retreat. The porch was my personal favorite but it only slightly won over Elizabeth's delicious breakfasts. Together with the serene environment, and wonderful summer evenings, I was able to return to the next day's meetings refreshed and re-energized. And, Elizabeth offered the wealth of information I needed to make the best use of my time between meetings. Although I was there for work, I felt as though I had a "mini" vacation. If you have a chance to stay for a day or a week, for business or pleasure, Alexander House Booklovers Bed and Breakfast will surely win a special place in your heart-forever.
reviews.title: A great weekend at Alexander House Booklovers B&B

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at this B&B for 2 nights last weekend. It was our second anniversary. Everything was wonderful. Our room (the Jane Austen room) was beautiful and spotless. The rest of the house was great, too. The breakfasts were delicious and there was very nice brandy at the end of the day. Our host, Elizabeth, was great. Full of information, directions and good conversation. And she sure can cook! It was exactly the kind of relaxing weekend that we were hoping for. Can't wait to go back!
reviews.title: Enchanted by the house and hostess!

reviews.text: If you're looking for a quiet, but fulfilling, retreat, this is the ideal spot. Centrally located to other charming areas, such as Berlin, Assateage and Crisfield, this B&B offers great food, a warm and accomodating hostess and a romantic atmosphere, devoid of the daily distractions of home/work. The Langston Hughes room was not only clean and comfy but fascinating as well. Do not miss the Honey-butter french toast prepared with the greatest of care by Elizabeth. The fact that it was an affordable stay only sweetens this already-attractive deal.
reviews.title: A Great Find

likes.liked: — Motif of rooms with quality furnishings, and cleanliness

reviews.title: One of most relaxing trips ever
reviews.text: Charming, quaint town... The Booklovers B and B was marvelous. Very upbeat yet peaceful, relaxing atmosphere. Mark Twain Room the best, Colette Cafe--colorful, whimsical--great music at night (Jazz and old time music).

reviews.title: Cozying up on the Eastern Shore
reviews.text: Innkeeper Elizabeth was wonderful; fantastic cook--we loved the crepes!

description: The Alexander House Booklovers' Bed & Breakfast is a literary-themed inn located in the quaint historic district of Princess Anne on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. The colorful Queen Anne Victorian features authors' portraits, dramatic colors and whimsical literary details throughout.Each room offers a creative interpretation of a famous author's own room in his or her time. Revel in the romance of Regency England in the Jane Austen Room. Immerse yourself in the jazzy Harlem Renaissance of the Langston Hughes Room; or a 19th-century high seas adventure in the Robert Louis Stevenson Room. Relax with a book from our eclectic library in the Mark Twain Library and Parlor. Partake of a hearty breakfast, afternoon tea or evening liqueur in the charmingly French Cafe Colette. All rooms have private bathrooms. Enjoy a relaxing stroll through the historic district of Princess Anne, teeming with lovingly preserved historic homes from the Colonial, Federal and Victorian eras. Walk to the nearby Teackle Mansion for a tour of one of Maryland's beautiful historic manses, then meander along the water in Manokin River Park. Take a walk down the quaint main street--featuring antique, coffee and gift shops, eateries.Local events include the annual Chesapeake Celtic Festival on the first weekend in October, (see link on local sights page) and the Annual Skipjack Races on Labor Day Weekend (local events link). Olde Princess Anne Days is celebrated in October with home and garden tours, carriage rides, street fair and more. Click on the Calendar of Events link on the Local Sights page for more annual events.Nestled between the beach (Atlantic) and the Bay (Chesapeake), nearby nature attractions include Assateague and Chincoteague (35 minute drive), where you can share the pristine, natural seashore with wild ponies. Or for some really wild night life, there's always Ocean City, a 30 minute drive away. Within minutes of various wildlife sanctuaries, rivers, waterways and marshes, where hundreds of bird species can be observed. Kayak and canoe rentals are available on the Pocomoke River or the Tangier Sound (opening to the Bay). A ferry boat ride away are Smith Island and Tangier Islands, where Colonial English/Cornish dialects are still spoken.
